prompt.p: A 31-year-old librarian presents with a 6-month history of weight loss, despite an increased appetite, having returned from a trip to Africa. Direct questioning also reveals a history of heat intolerance, tremor and weakness. She also complains of double vision. Examination reveals proptosis. You note her heart rate appears irregular.

modalFeedback.p: Option C is Correct. Diplopia, proptosis, chemosis and periorbital oedema are signs specific to Graves’ disease.
Option A is Incorrect. Bacterial endocarditis does not present with eyelid retraction and lid lag.
Option B is Incorrect. Cushing's syndrome is not associated with diplopia or weight loss.
Option D is Incorrect. Of the options given, option C is more accurate given the ocular signs and symptoms described in the question.

Option E is Incorrect. Although malaria may present with weight loss, tremor, weakness and palpitations, it does not cause proptosis or atrial fibrillation. These symptoms are consistent with Graves’ disease.
